Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Hurricane Sandy, Disaster Recovery, and the Seeds of Urban Transformation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This RAPID response research project investigates the impact of Hurricane Sandy on future coastal development in heavily damaged communities in New Jersey and New York. Drawing from new innovations in socio-ecological transition theory, the study tests the hypothesis that that critical transitions or regime shifts can be precipitated by external shocks events, such as major natural disasters. Using a transition framework, the study explores whether Hurricane Sandy and the responses to the severe storm surge damage from the hurricane have created conditions that may lead to a transformation of settlement patterns of the New York-New Jersey (NY-NJ) Metropolitan Region coastal zone. Research for the study entails documentation and analysis of the types and character of responses and actions that are being considered or are just underway by individual property and business owners, government officials at the municipal, county, state, and federal levels, and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) in a representative set of four heavily impacted coastal communities in New Jersey and New York (two in each state). The application of a transition framework to the assessment of responses taken in the short-term aftermath of Hurricane Sandy presents a unique opportunity to advance theoretical and applied understanding of how extreme disaster events set in motion fundamental, socio-ecological system shifts within vulnerable and at risk areas of large metropolitan regions. This project contributes to fundamental understanding of how new types of disaster events emerging with climate change might affect coastal development patterns in urbanized areas of the United States.

Within the United States and globally, disaster risk reduction policies and strategies have emphasized using lessons from the past events in order to understand what should be avoided in the future. Yet growing recognition of the non-stationarity of the climate is compelling individuals operating at all levels, from local communities to the federal government, to look at Hurricane Sandy and other similar extreme events in a different way. In particular, there is growing recognition that coastal properties, infrastructure, and larger interconnected, urban systems cannot be rebuilt with the simple goal of reducing vulnerability to the last event and that the rebuilding effort must allow for much greater resilience in the future. This study provides invaluable information about factors that promote or hinder resilience within large, coastal urban systems. Results of the study are to be disseminated via public presentations to local and regional stakeholders and through policy documents and research articles. With respect to traineeship opportunities, the study facilitates the training of graduate students at Rutgers University and City University of New York in rapid response climate change impact and adaptation assessment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This RAPID response research project investigated the impact of Hurricane Sandy on future coastal development in heavily damaged communities in New Jersey and New York. Focusing on the actions and experiences of homeowners and community leaders, the major goal of study was to document the short-lived evidence of the initial phase of transition in coastal communities that were heavily impacted by Hurricane Sandy’s storm surge and flooding. A secondary goal was to determine how and under what conditions might a profound neighborhood transformation emerge, such as the development and implementation of a large-scale property buyout program or rezoning policy focused on limited redevelopment of parcels in high storm surge sites.

 

The project addressed two sets of research questions: 1. What stress and crisis conditions are local property owners and community leaders facing as a result of Hurricane Sandy?; and, 2. Do the immediate responses of these stakeholders to Hurricane Sandy provide early signals that transitions in the study sites have occurred, and whether a large-scale change or transformation is likely to occur.  Answers to these questions were determined from face to face surveys with 60 property owners and interviews with 15 local government officials. Surveys and interviews were conducted in four communities, two in coastal New York and two in coastal New Jersey. The questions focused on post Hurricane Sandy stress and crisis conditions, and on the resilience of the property owners and communities. The study also documented information on the locations of Sandy-related buyouts of flood-prone properties both within the study site area and over the extended New York-New Jersey metropolitan region. Photographic evidence and written records provided additional documentation of changes in the communities and policies and actions affecting the communities, as documented in the interviews.

 

The results of the analysis showed that half of the sixty homeowners surveyed evacuated during the Hurricane and remained out of their homes for an average of four months. Among those who evacuated, almost all incurred some damage to their homes and about two-thirds of the evacuated homes were uninhabitable immediately post-Sandy. Regarding their plans for long-term occupancy after Sandy, half of those who experienced home damage planned to repair their properties to pre-Sandy conditions, about one-third sought buyouts or were looking to sell, and a much smaller percentage wanted to repair their homes, but make the property more resilient compared to pre-Sandy conditions. Most decisions regarding long-term occupancy were made within the first week after the storm, although many decided over a longer period of time (i.e., several months), with some still undecided over a year out from the storm. Those who decided right away generally wanted to stay and rebuild, while those who wanted to seek a buy-out took much longer to make this decision. Overall, the respondents represented moderate to lower-income working class households where property costs were an important factor in their decisions whether or not to remain in their houses.
